Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Terahertz semiconductor laser sources for operation above cryogenic temperatures

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal ECCS 1150071

Project Abstract

Objective
The research objective of this proposal is the investigation and development of widely and continuously tunable terahertz quantum-cascade lasers and other active devices based upon monolithic and voltage tunable metamaterial waveguides. These waveguides are based on the transmission-line metamaterial concept in which the dispersion relation is tuned by electrical control of integrated capacitive elements. Goals include demonstration of widely tunable terahertz laser sources in various configurations, including tunable distributed feedback lasers, tunable master-oscillator power-amplifiers, and beam-steerable phased-array THz laser emitters.

Intellectual Merit
The intellectual merit is the integration of tunable metamaterial concepts with laser waveguides, in which propagation is sensitively dependent on values of embedded circuit elements. This approach can achieve a much wider range of tunability than can be achieved using temperature or other electrical techniques, with a high degree of monolithic integration. The demonstration of amplifier and distributed feedback configurations will allow the output power to be scaled to several milliwatts or greater with a directive beam pattern.

Broader Impacts
The broader impacts lie in the development of a new approach for achieving tunable semiconductor lasers. Additionally, terahertz technology requires improved sources and detectors for sensing, imaging, and spectroscopy. The core of the educational plan is to enhance undergraduate research within the Electrical Engineering department through the development of a coordinated publicity, outreach, and training program, as well as directly employing undergraduates in this research. Multiple campus resources will be leveraged to attract and fund underrepresented minority students to this research and engineering in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Terahertz (0.5-5 THz) radiation is widely used for imaging, spectroscopy, and sensing. It is highly desired to develop mass-producible electrically-pumped room-temperature THz sources, similar diode lasers in infrared/visible range. Semiconductor quantum cascade lasers (QCLs) can operate in the THz, but only at cryogenic temperatures. In this project we developed QCL architecture that resulted in the first mass-producible broadly-tunable THz QCL sources with mW-level THz power output at room temperature. To that end, we introduced giant optical nonlinearity for terahertz difference-frequency generation (DFG) in high-power room-temperature mid-infrared QCLs using the principles of intersubband bandstructure engineering. We have further developed laser waveguides to enable Chernekov phase-matching scheme for DFG that allowed extraction of THz radiation along the entire length of the laser waveguide. As a result, we created devices with high-power broadly-tunable THz output at room-temperature. Up to 300 microwatts of peak power output is demonstrated in our group at room temperature and up to 2mW is demonstrated by others, based on the device architecture developed in this project. Continuous-wave room-temperature powers up to 14 microwatts are also demonstrated. Furthermore, we demonstrated broad spectral tuning in 1-6 THz range and experimentally confirmed narrow emission linewidth (<1MHz) in continuous-wave devices.

THz DFG-QCL devices developed over the course of this project are currently the only monolithic electrically-pumped sources of THz radiation that can be produced in mass quantities in semiconductor laser foundries.
